Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Panhandle Pipeline (P2) project is designed to recruit, retain, and improve the performance of students obtaining science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) degrees.

The objectives of the project are to:
1. Provide scholarships to least 20 students per year and at least 60 overall who are majoring in STEM fields, with an emphasis on underrepresented students. Students come from three groups: financially-needy recent high school graduates, adult students, and undeclared college students who exhibit academic promise in STEM programs.
2. Coordinate and integrate resources to increase academic success and graduate with an associate degree at least 65% of the scholarship students in STEM majors.
3. Partner with West Texas A&M University (WTAMU) to facilitate a seamless transfer for STEM majors.

Intellectual Merit: The goals are to improve the performance of STEM students enrolled at the college; increase the quantity, quality, and diversity of STEM students obtaining associate degrees; and promoting transfer to a four-year university. The college is partnering in this project with the NSF-funded WTAMU S-STEM Community College Transfer for STEM Success program, which provides scholarships to community college transfer students in STEM disciplines and thus creates a seamless pathway to a four-year degree.

Broader Impacts: The college is an Hispanic Serving Institution with an enrollment of over 11,000 students, 28% of whom are Hispanic. P2 is increasing the quantity and quality of STEM graduates by providing scholarships and academic enhancement activities. Since most of the graduates from the college enter the regional workforce or transfer to WTAMU, increasing the STEM abilities of students is having a great impact on increasing the capacity of the STEM workforce in the region.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Amarillo College is very encouraged by the outcomes from our National Science Foundation Scholarships for STEM Majors grant (award ID 1059696). Including a one-year no cost extension, the grant period ran from June 1, 2011 to May 31, 2016. During the grant period, we awarded $515,069 in scholarships (228 awards) to 123 individual students pursuing STEM majors. The average total award (all scholarships received) per student was $4,187.55 and was based on need. Underserved populations for STEM majors who participated include 41.5 percent female students and 54.5 percent Hispanic and minority race students.

Significant success milestones were achieved by the participating students:

123 (100 percent) Students received one or more scholarship awards from fall 2011 through spring 2017

111 (90.2 percent) Graduated, transferred, or left AC

12 (9.8 percent) Still active at AC or another community college (since spring 2016)

 

70 (63.1 percent) Completed AS or AAS degree at AC (70/111)

56 (80.0 percent) Of degrees completed at AC are STEM (56/70)

67 (60.4 percent) Transferred to 4 yr university within one year of leaving AC (67/111)

4 (3.6 percent) Delayed transfer to 4 yr university after leaving AC (4/111)

71 (64.0 percent) TOTAL transfers                                                          

                                                                               

28 (39.4 percent) Already completed Bachelor's degree after transfer (28/71)

35 (49.3 percent) Still working on Bachelor's - enrolled within past year (35/71)

 

Success measures by highest level of completion (unduplicated headcount):

25 (22.5 percent) Students completing AS/AAS degree at AC with no indication of transfer yet                                                              

26 (23.4 percent) Students completing AS/AAS degree at AC and transferred to 4 yr university

14 (12.6 percent) Students transferred to 4 yr university (no degree from AC) and still working on Bachelor's                        

28 (25.2 percent) Students completing AS/AAS degree and/or transferred to 4 yr university and completed Bachelor's

 

TOTAL success milestones:

93 (83.8 percent) of the students who have left AC have completed one or more success milestones (93/111)

 

STEM success:

80.0 percent of completed AS/AAS degrees were STEM (56/70)

84.5 percent of transfers were to a STEM major (60/71)

85.7 percent of completed Bachelor's drgrees were STEM (24/28)

 

Note:  7 of the students are currently enrolled in graduate school    

 

Impact of receiving the NSF S-STEM scholarship as reported by two of our students:

“The STEM program at Amarillo College not only helped me financially, but kept my motivation up and helped me complete my Associate degree and gave me the courage to apply and be successful at a university. I could not have finished without the guidance and encouragement of my advisors from the STEM program.”    

“I was going through a hard time when I was going to AC and the STEM scholarship helped out tremendously. Before the STEM scholarship, I was highly considering taking a year break from school or going part time. I figured I wouldn't get my degree for another two years and I am so thankful to have had the opportunity to finish school in a timely manner. Thank you!” 


Last Modified: 08/30/2017
Modified by: Claudie J Biggers
